item.title: Covid vaccine: All UK adults to be offered jab by 31 July - PM
item.description: Boris Johnson says there will be "no let up", as he prepares to set out his plan to ease lockdown.

item.title: Duke of Edinburgh: Prince Charles visits his father in hospital
item.description: The Duke of Edinburgh, 99, was admitted to King Edward VII Hospital in central London on Tuesday.

item.title: Covid-19: Fewest firms planning job cuts since pandemic began
item.description: The figures suggest the decision to extend the furlough scheme has helped to prevent wider job losses.

item.title: US plane scatters engine debris over Denver homes
item.description: The Honolulu-bound Boeing suffered engine failure but returned safely to Denver airport.

item.title: Lockdown review: What are the risks of schools, pubs and shops reopening?
item.description: Lockdown could slowly be lifted soon but what are the risks associated with relaxing certain restrictions?

item.title: Myanmar coup: At least two killed as police disperse protesters
item.description: Reports from the scene say police used live ammunition at the rally in the city of Mandalay.

item.title: Swimming teacher is youngest woman to row Atlantic
item.description: Twenty-one-year-old Jasmine Harrison says the "amazing" row was "everything I wanted it to be".

item.title: Cambridge moonflower: Wait over for 'UK's first' bloom
item.description: The plant's first bloom is a "real treat" for thousands waiting to watch it flower online.

item.title: Friedrich Karl Berger: US deports ex-concentration camp guard to Germany
item.description: Friedrich Karl Berger, 95, worked at the Nazi Neuengamme camp during World War Two.

item.title: Bird flu: Russia detects first case of H5N8 bird flu in humans
item.description: Workers have been infected at a poultry plant - but there is no sign of transmission between humans.

item.title: Greece #Metoo: Prominent actor Dimitris Lignadis held over rape accusations
item.description: The ex-boss of Greece's national theatre faces underage rape allegations - the charges he denies.

item.title: Texas weather: President Biden declares major disaster
item.description: As electricity slowly returns to Texas, many residents still do not have access to running water.

item.title: Confusion over Wales' incoming smacking ban
item.description: When asked, 23% said there knew of the changes and 26% said they knew but were unsure of details.

item.title: The Papers: Jabs ‘for all adults’ by July and ‘free by summer’
item.description: Sunday’s papers are dominated by Boris Johnson’s pledge to offer every UK adult a vaccine by 31 July.

item.title: Kangaroo Island dunnart: Saving a bushfire-ravaged marsupial
item.description: Already critically endangered, Australia's Kangaroo Island dunnart has lost most of its habitat.

item.title: The homemade special effects livening up lockdown
item.description: Peter Quinn moved from Northern Ireland to America to work in the VFX industry over a decade ago.

item.title: May Willis: 'I'm almost 111 and make the most of what I've got'
item.description: May Willis, from Bexhill, credits her long life to no smoking, no alcohol - and lots of chocolate.

item.title: Covid: 'Each one of these people mattered'
item.description: Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg is using art to show the "depth and breadth" of Covid's US death toll.

item.title: Pablo Hasel: Luxury stores looted and vehicles ablaze in Barcelona protests
item.description: The arrest of the Catalan rapper has ignited ignited a debate over freedom of speech in Spain.

item.title: ICYMI: An ice carousel, a wallaby and a mammoth tooth
item.description: Here are some of the stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Essex lockdown one-man choir of nine singers
item.description: A musician uses technology to turn himself into a one-man lockdown choir of nine singers.

item.title: Mars landing: Photo shows Perseverance about to touch down
item.description: Nasa releases an astonishing image of its new Mars robot taken just moments before touchdown.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Don't ask me which vaccine is best, please
item.description: Dr John Wright says he's often asked which vaccine is best, but the answer is it's too early to say.

item.title: How Trump offered Kim a ride on Air Force One
item.description: A new BBC series shows how threats of nuclear war against North Korea gave way to a Trump-Kim bromance.

item.title: Are streaming algorithms really damaging film?
item.description: Director Martin Scorsese says streaming algorithms demean cinema and treat viewers as consumers.

item.title: How European businesses are adapting to Brexit
item.description: Companies doing business between Europe and the UK talk to the BBC about the impact of the new rules.

item.title: Covid-19: Which countries in Africa are administering vaccines?
item.description: Some African nations have just begun vaccination programmes, but many have yet to start.

item.title: The petrol that was poisoning children
item.description: How a successful campaign led to the banning of lead in petrol in the UK

item.title: Netflix and Anna Delvey: The race to secure the story of New York's 'fake heiress'
item.description: How Anna Sorokin's life rights became hot property.

item.title: 'Chess player' Medvedev aiming to end Djokovic's dominance
item.description: Novak Djokovic goes for a record ninth Australian Open title as Russia's Daniil Medvedev attempts to win his first Grand Slam.

item.title: Fulham move three points behind Newcastle after beating Sheff Utd
item.description: Ademola Lookman's goal boosts Fulham's hopes of Premier League survival as they claim a vital win over fellow strugglers Sheffield United.

item.title: Britain's Kelly loses unbeaten record as Avanesyan wins in sixth
item.description: Josh Kelly loses his first professional fight as Russian David Avanesyan defends his European welterweight title with a sixth-round win at Wembley Arena.

item.title: Charged-down conversion secures Northampton dramatic win at champions Exeter
item.description: Northampton charge down an aborted last-gasp conversion by Joe Simmonds to inflict a second home league defeat on Exeter.

item.title: Penalty claim, VAR controversy & a red card - incident-packed return for referee Dean
item.description: After a month of controversies, referee Mike Dean is again in the spotlight for an incident-filled game on his return at Turf Moor.

item.title: Whyte's rematch with Povetkin put back three weeks
item.description: Dillian Whyte's rematch with Russian Alexander Povetkin is put back three weeks to 27 March in Gibraltar.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK, so when might you get one?

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Is the Covid vaccine safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Covid: What are the UK's lockdown rules and when will they end?
item.description: People across the country have been urged to "double down" and stick to the lockdown rules.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: More people have been added to the clinically extremely vulnerable list in England. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Vaccine passports: Do I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The growing number of people vaccinated may be able to gain more freedoms in the future.

item.title: Covid: When will schools reopen?
item.description: Boris Johnson is expected to focus on the re-opening of schools is his "roadmap" for easing lockdown.

item.title: Covax: How will Covid vaccines be shared around the world?
item.description: A scheme to distribute Covid-19 vaccines globally is under way. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Coronavirus: Has the NHS got enough of the right PPE?
item.description: Who needs it - and does the UK health service have the right kit?

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of a new variant of Covid-19.

item.title: What is a challenge trial and why do we need them?
item.description: Some volunteers in the UK will be deliberately infected with coronavirus in a "challenge trial".

item.title: Covid: Claims vaccinations harm fertility unfounded
item.description: Social-media posts - some described as "scare stories" - are based on misunderstandings, experts say.

item.title: Fake Covid videos 'will cost lives'
item.description: Sima Kotecha follows the origins of a "dangerous" viral video about a false Covid-19 treatment.

item.title: Covid: How will we know if the vaccine is working?
item.description: Deaths are falling faster for the over-80s - but does that mean the vaccine is working?

item.title: Murmurations above supermarket 'wow' shoppers
item.description: The flock started to settle in trees near Asda, on Hall Road, Norwich at the weekend.

item.title: Swansea blitz: Childhood memories of 'bombing horror', 80 years on
item.description: The Three Nights' Blitz began on 19 February 1941, killing 230 and injuring nearly 400.

item.title: 'I rescued my son after lightning set fire to our home'
item.description: Kerry Quinn stumbled upstairs through the smoke to reach her sleeping teenage son, before taking him out to safety.

item.title: Handforth Parish Council Zoom meeting dogged by rows again
item.description: Thousands tune in for the latest Handforth Parish Council meeting but Jackie Weaver is not present.

item.title: Coronavirus: Should university students get a refund?
item.description: The pandemic has meant most students have been unable to go to lectures - so should they get a refund?
